content.description:
“We need first to seize Le CapCap Haitien, a coastal town in Haiti in a spontaneous attack. By not giving them a chance to realize what is happening, we will surprise them with the help of the mulattoes and blacks, free and slave, on our side. And as Le Cap is the heart of the colony and its stronghold, once it is taken, the rest of the colony will be easy for us.... [Slaves from neighboring regions] will set fire to the plantations on their way to Le Cap. They will burn the big houses, kill the [enslavers], and seize their arms and ammunition, and then join their comrades...who will already be in front of Le Cap. This plot is known to all the slaves in the colony, it involves everyone, and the object is to take over the country.”
Source: François and Dechaussée, planning the start of the Haitian Revolution in a meeting at Lenormand Plantation, 1791
content.question: Which of the following best explains how the Haitian Revolution provides useful context for understanding the territorial expansion of slavery in the United States?

choices.label: The cost of fighting the Haitian revolutionaries motivated France to sell its territory in North America to the United States.
With the end of slavery in Haiti, the United States increased cotton production to offset the decline of cotton production in Haiti.
Sympathy motivated the United States government to encourage the immigration of white planters from Haiti.
The failure of the Haitian Revolution encouraged supporters of slavery in the United States to expand the institution to the West.

content.answer: The cost of fighting the Haitian revolutionaries motivated France to sell its territory in North America to the United States.

skill.text: 1.B: Identify and explain the context of a specific event, development, or process.
